info.game_comments:
2003 Back to School Week game 1.
Game data retrieved from an alternate archive.

(1, 1).clue: Covering 64 million square miles, it's the largest ocean in the world

(2, 1).clue: Actress Diaz' name, it means "crooked nose"

(3, 1).clue: It was the first film in which Harrison Ford played Dr. Henry Jones, Jr.

(4, 1).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew presents from the beach.) It's named for what it was doing before it washed up on the beach, and you can use it to build a fire

(5, 1).clue: Classy earrings & bracelets are made with the small seed type of this gem from the ocean

(6, 1).clue: Enjoyed a book, or a primary color

(1, 2).clue: Saltier than any ocean, the Great Salt Lake is the largest lake in this western U.S. State

(2, 2).clue: Young actress Larson, or a type of cheese

(3, 2).clue: It was the 2002 sequel to Disney's 1953 classic "Peter Pan"

(4, 2).clue: Water binds grains of sand using surface tension; that'll help you build this, complete with moat

(5, 2).clue: A 1998 Harvard study found a link between arthritis of the knee & this type of women's shoe

(6, 2).clue: Moved like the wind, or a primary color

(1, 3).clue: Important rivers in this country include the Huang He & the Yangtze

(2, 3).clue: This first name of model Harlow means "peace" in Hebrew

(3, 3).clue: In this 2003 film the Pickles meet the Thornberrys

(4, 3).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew presents from the beach)This word can mean part of a touchdown celebration in football, or this volleyball move

(5, 3).clue: For a fancy event, dress up in white tie & these, which animals have but humans usually don't

(6, 3).clue: A penny, or mailed a letter

(1, 4).clue: The Strait of Dover connects this channel with the North Sea

(2, 4).clue: There's no doubt this Welsh name belonging to No Doubt's singer means "fair"

(3, 4).clue: In this 2002 film Dennis Quaid played a high school baseball coach who tries out for the big leagues

(4, 4).clue: "Celebrate the sun" in safety with the brand of sunblock called this "Boat"

(5, 4).clue: A bride may wear a tiara to keep this clothing item in place

(6, 4).clue: Walk through water, or determined the heaviness of something

(1, 5).clue: This river stretches 4,160 miles from Burundi to the Mediterranean Sea

(2, 5).clue: It's the first male name in "20,001 Names for Baby"

(3, 5).clue: In this 2000 film Tulio & Miguel, 2 swindlers, get their hands on a map to a fabled city of gold

(4, 5).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew presents from the beach)This board, similar to a boogie board, is named for the milky way you move across the water on it

(5, 5).clue: Centuries ago the length of this long, trailing part of a dress indicated social rank

(1, 1).clue: In 1902 he began working at the Swiss Patent Office; his theory of relativity came 3 years later

(2, 1).clue: ... to Hannibal, Missouri, where we saw this author's boyhood home, & an actual cave featured in his "Tom Sawyer"

(3, 1).clue: The Nina, Pinta & Santa Maria were under his command

(4, 1).clue: In an 1898 peace treaty, this country had to give up Cuba -- that's what you get for messing with Uncle Sam

(5, 1).clue: Rimsky-Korsakov wrote an opera about this Czar who was so scary people called him "the terrible"

(1, 2).clue: For his "enlightening" inventions, he was called the "Wizard of Menlo Park"

(2, 2).clue: ... to Washington, D.C., where we got to tour this agency's headquarters & see its ten most wanted list

(3, 2).clue: In cartoons, his nephews are Huey, Dewey & Louie

(4, 2).clue: A treaty signed in San Francisco in 1951 officially ended the war with this Pearl Harbor attacker

(5, 2).clue: "Under the Double Moon" takes place on Undine, a watery one of these (We think it must be like Neptune)

(1, 3).clue: In March 1876 he received a patent for an apparatus for "transmitting vocal or other sounds"

(2, 3).clue: ... "Down Under" to this country, where we got to explore the Great Barrier Reef

(3, 3).clue: Unnamed in the Bible, these visitors to the baby Jesus are traditionally aka Balthasar, Melchior & Gaspar
(3, 3).correct response: the Three Kings (or Three Wise Men)

(4, 3).clue: n 1865 his second inaugural address asked for "a just and lasting peace, among ourselves, and with all nations"

(5, 3).clue: In a famous comic opera from 1930, this facial feature gets detached from its owner & "runs" away

(6, 3).clue: A short, shrill sound made by a mouse or a hinge

(1, 4).clue: On Dec. 17, 1903, in North Carolina, they took 4 quick trips -- the shortest, 12 sec.; the longest, 59 sec.

(2, 4).clue: ... over Christmas, to California, where on January 1 we attended this famous football game in Pasadena

(3, 4).clue: In a nursery rhyme, the butcher, the baker & the candlestick maker are the 3 men in one of these

(4, 4).clue: In 1669 Clement IX, holder of this position, made peace in a religious battle within France

(5, 4).clue: In Wagner's "Ring" cycle, Fafner is a big scary giant who turns into one of these fire-breathing mythical beasts

(6, 4).clue: The pointed top of a mountain, or the mountain itself

(1, 5).clue: In 1666, using a prism, this English scientist discovered that sunlight is made up of different colors

(2, 5).clue: ... to Grand Rapids, Michigan, where we visited this former President's library & museum

(3, 5).clue: Literature's Athos, Porthos & Aramis were this swashbuckling trio

(4, 5).clue: David Trimble & John Hume won the Nobel Peace Prize for their work in the northern part of this island

(5, 5).clue: In "The Ghosts of Versailles", the ghost of this French queen moans about losing her head on the guillotine

(6, 5).clue: Dismal & depressing, like the title "house" in a Dickens novel

(0, 0).clue: John Singleton Copley's portrait of Paul Revere hangs in the Museum of Fine Arts in this city
